title: call with mindsie 1
description:
Soren Frederikse and Bill Karpovich

Soren Frederikse and Bill Karpovich
Transcript

https://otter.ai/u/wWb8oBXX7DiRELZ72wqhxR_blS4?view=summary

Soren Frederiksen and Bill Karpovich discussed the potential collaboration between Soren's process mining company, Mindsey, and Bill's company. Soren highlighted Mindsey's tech stack, which includes a no-code platform for process mining and task mining, and their experience with on-premise solutions. Bill expressed interest in leveraging Mindsey's technology for their next-generation task and process mining platform, targeting the US market. They agreed to schedule a technical call to explore further, focusing on Mindsey's capabilities and potential integration with Bill's company's offerings.

Action Items
[ ] @Soren Frederiksen - Schedule a technical call between Soren, Bill, and Bill's partner.
[ ] @Soren Frederiksen - Provide a platform overview and demo of Mindzie's capabilities, especially in the healthcare industry.
Outline
Soren's Background and Current Location
Soren Frederiksen mentions he is in a lake house north of Toronto, about two hours away from the city.
Bill Karpovich shares his familiarity with Toronto, mentioning his son's hockey trips and his previous role at IBM.
Soren explains his move to the lake house after his kids moved out and the convenience of remote work during COVID-19.
Bill inquires about Soren's ability to connect and the context of their conversation.
Bill's Company and Market Opportunity
Bill explains his company's focus on task mining and process mining, seeing a significant opportunity in the next generation of these technologies.
He highlights the importance of understanding processes securely and linking them to AI-based solutions.
Bill mentions the company's history of building successful products and their current early product development stage.
He seeks a strong, innovative technology leader to help bring their product to market and execute their strategy.
Soren's Company and Process Mining Experience
Soren provides an overview of his company, Mindsey, which started five years ago and has a full tech stack.
He mentions his partner, James Henderson, and their experience in the process mining space, including their platform's ability to go on-premise.
Soren discusses the challenges of selling process mining in the US compared to Europe, where it has been more established.
He explains their strategy of focusing on outcomes rather than the process maps themselves.
Challenges and Market Dynamics
Soren shares his concerns about the US market's slow adoption of process mining and the challenges of selling to US companies.
He mentions the impact of companies like Celonis and Appromote being bought by larger entities, which has affected the market dynamics.
Soren discusses the importance of having a data strategy and the challenges of dealing with siloed databases in large companies.
Bill and Soren discuss the potential for task mining and its limitations, particularly in terms of privacy and installation time.
Soren's Approach to Process Mining
Soren explains his preference for process mining over task mining due to its lower cost and fewer privacy issues.
He shares his experience with task mining in a few cases but generally finds it less practical.
Soren discusses the importance of understanding the customer's needs and the challenges of implementing task mining in large organizations.
Bill and Soren discuss the potential for task mining in specific scenarios and the overall market dynamics.
Soren's Company's Tech Stack and Market Position
Soren describes their tech stack as modern and capable of handling both process and task mining.
He explains their approach of connecting directly to source systems rather than using a centralized data warehouse.
Soren highlights the flexibility of their platform, which can be hosted on-premise or in the cloud.
Bill expresses interest in learning more about Soren's company and their approach to process mining.
Potential Collaboration and Next Steps
Bill inquires about the possibility of a partnership or OEM agreement with Soren's company.
Soren expresses openness to consulting and sharing their knowledge, but emphasizes his commitment to his current partner.
They discuss the potential for a technical call to explore collaboration further.
Bill and Soren agree to schedule a follow-up call to discuss their platform and potential collaboration in more detail.
Soren's Experience with Healthcare and On-Premise Solutions
Soren shares his experience with healthcare clients, including Motorola and Ottawa Hospital, and the challenges of implementing process mining in this sector.
He discusses the importance of on-premise solutions for healthcare organizations and the limitations of cloud-only solutions.
Soren mentions their ability to host their platform on various cloud providers and their experience with hosting in Saudi Arabia.
Bill and Soren discuss the potential for collaboration in the healthcare sector and the challenges of working with large, complex organizations.
Final Remarks and Scheduling
Bill and Soren agree to schedule a technical call for Monday or Tuesday to discuss Soren's platform in more detail.
Soren offers to include his partner, James, in the call if needed.
They discuss the format of the call and the focus on learning about Soren's platform rather than a sales pitch.
Bill and Soren conclude the call, expressing mutual interest in exploring potential collaboration opportunities.

who's doing well in the space. Do you think

Bill Karpovich  24:13  
So, yeah, it's the ultimately, the outcome on the data side. Is it staying inside of their DMZ somehow? Is it, you know, other techniques to really, somehow cut get through the data access challenges?

Soren Frederiksen  24:38  
Yeah, it is. We've taken a couple of swings at this. And because we didn't, we started with customers like we started with Motorola, but we got in because of a friend, not because they had a demand. So it was kind of the wrong customer we were in with. So the customers we've learned from in the US, I thought that people had their data warehouse further along, right? So we thought we can just dip into the data warehouse and get the data. That's not the case, right? That's the rarity. You find somebody that has the data available in data warehouse. We tried to build our own, and we did partially do our own warehouse instead of because we were SOC, two certified. So if you go out and use another provider, now you have two different people in the contract, right? So it gets tricky to do that. So we tried to build our own. We did build our own, but it was too hard to maintain to keep our own data warehouse. So now what we do is we only go to source systems and we can connect to 20 but it has to have a database behind it. So if it has a query language, we can connect to it, and then we just ingest the data directly. And that means if you're going into something that has an API, we can't connect to it unless it's transferred into a database first. But we've kind of made that choice right now, because if you have a database, you extract out of I can just write five queries, run them nightly, and I can directly pull data out. So we kind of stopped salon is like, force you to use their data warehouse for instance, right? And they probably also make some money on it. I think it's a really bad choice in the long run, because a company shouldn't choose salon is for the data warehouse because of process mining, they should have their data warehouse and then choose a one or many process mining vendors out of there, right? So, so we so that's the approach we're taking right now. So SAP is a big one we pull out of, or Oracle we pull out of for hospitals, and there we just go directly to the database and get what we need. Yeah, so we just get a read connection and and that, the good thing about that is the cost for us, like running the queries is minimal, right? We don't have the warehousing of their data.
